Summary: SC 28.2.24 Isolated accumulations developing on N to E aspects above 900m. Firm elsewhere. Avalanche hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: Very hard snow ice on exposed windward slopes. Cloud base was at 700 metres all day. Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: Thaw conditions overnight. New snow during the day.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight the freezing level will be above the summits with rain at all levels. By dawn the freezing level will be around 600 metres with light snow showers during the day.  Gale force winds from the South-West throughout the period.
SnowStability: After overnight thaw conditions, older snow is expected to become firmer, particularly at higher levels.  New windslab accumulations that develop over older snow-ice will be isolated and generally inconsequential. These deposits will be found in wind sheltered features such as corrie rims and gully tops on North to East facing aspects above 900 metres. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A cloudy but generally dry day. The freezing level was around 900 metres for most of the period. Strong winds from the South-West throughout.
ObservedSnowStability: Overall, the snow cover is thawing and diminishing in extent but localised areas of windslab persist, mainly on North to East aspects above 1000 metres. Steep, wind sheltered features such as corrie rims and gully tops are most affected. High exposed areas are still very firm and icy. Any remaining cornices are unstable. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: CM for 29/02  Stability declining progressively on N to E aspects above 900m. Cornices! Avalanche hazard Considerable.
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout.  No visibility throughout the day above 600 metres.  Winds 30-40 mph, progress difficult and tiring, blowing us over on occasions.
Comment: Period of poorest stability expected to be later in the day.
WeatherInfluences: Remaining mild until midnight then progressively much colder. Overnight rain showers turning to snow showers, which will continue for the rest of the period. Strong South West winds.
SnowStability: Overnight the old moist snowpack will refreeze and become well stabilized in all locations. New accumulations of weakly bonded windslab will begin to accumulate on all steep North to East aspects above 900 metres during the morning. Stability will decline progressively in these locations over the course of the day, becoming poor later. New weak cornice development anticipated over steeper lee slopes. The avalanche hazard will be Considerable.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Dry overnight. Sleety snow showers turned to light rain at all levels during the morning. Initially cold but much milder from noon onwards. Moderate South-West winds increased to strong later.
ObservedSnowStability: Moist but well bonded snow in most locations below 900 metres. Some localised wet snow instability late in the period on steep North to East aspects above 950 metres. Wet, weak cornices remain in a few places though debris from several are present on the North facing crag apron in the Inner Coire of Coire Ardair.  The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: TO for 29.02 Localised areas of unstable windslab N-E aspects above 800m. Avalanche Hazard Low.
SnowDistribution: Thawing at all levels. Clear in the morning, cloudy on the tops in the afternoon.  Winds approx 40 - 50 mph.
Comment: A relatively dry and bright day forecast for Friday with light winds and temperatures on the summits remaining sub-zero.
WeatherInfluences: South-Westerly strong to gale force winds. Showers throughout the forecast period turning to snow from midnight onwards. The freezing level lowers to around 600 metres.
SnowStability: Fresh unstable windslab will develop on North to East aspects above 800 metres. Areas affected will be steep wind sheltered locations such as gully tops and corrie rims. These accumulations are expected to be localised and easily avoidable. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: South-South-Westerly gale force winds. A dry morning with some bright spells followed by rain showers in the afternoon. The freezing level rose to well above the summits by mid-day.
ObservedSnowStability: Thaw conditions at all levels. Any remaining snow is confined to steep North through East to South-East aspects above 800 metres. The snowpack continues to consolidate and is generally stable. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: GC 29/02. Fresh unstable windslab will build on N to E aspects above 850m. Cornices will be fragile. Moderate Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Diminishing snowpack at all levels, with deeper accumulations above 800 metres. Cloudy on the tops with light rain and drizzle.  Winds approx 40 - 50 mph making progress very difficult and strenuous.
Comment: Turning wintery with outlook for Friday to become drier.
WeatherInfluences: Precipitation falling as rain above summit levels this evening will turn to snow through the night, as the freezing level lowers to 500 metres. Snow showers continue above this level throughout the day, prolonged at times. South-Westerly winds will be gale force, gusting storm force, throughout the period.
SnowStability: The old snowpack will continue to consolidate during Wednesday evening. Fresh deposits of unstable windslab will build through the remainder of the period, especially in the afternoon, on mainly North to East aspects above 850 metres. Greatest accumulations will be in steep wind sheltered locations around coire rims, head walls, gullies and crag aprons. Cornices will be fragile. Areas exposed to the wind will begin to refreeze and will be stable. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A cloudy day with early light rain and periods of drizzle. Feeling milder with the freezing level rising above the summits. Winds were strong to gale force from a South-Westerly direction.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack is moist and generally diminishing at all elevations in today\'s milder conditions. However, instabilities in the snowpack remain in deeper accumulations on mainly North to East aspects above 850 metres. Areas greatest affected are coire rims, head walls, gullies and crag aprons. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.

Summary: LO for 29/2. Fresh areas of windslab developing through the day on N to E aspects above 800m. Moderate avalanche hazard.
SnowDistribution: Snowpack becoming wet through the day.  A day of flat light and no definition at higher levels.  Winds approx 40 - 50 mph.
Comment: Existing snowpack likely to turn firm and icy in the colder conditions. Significant slip hazard.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight the freezing level will drop to around 600 metres where it will remain through the day. Showers, initially falling as rain will turn to snow above 500 metres and continue through the day. Strong winds will be from the South-West.
SnowStability: The existing wet snowpack will freeze and consolidate overnight as the freezing level drops. However, through the latter part of the night and the day fresh areas of unstable windslab will be deposited on mainly North to East aspects above 800 metres. These areas will increase in depth and extent through the day.  The tops of slopes and gullies being most affected. Windward aspects will tend to be scoured and stable.  The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Overnight and through the morning showers fell as snow above about 800 metres. Around midday the freezing level rose above the summits and showery precipitation turned to rain at all levels. Gale force winds were from the South-West.
ObservedSnowStability: Overnight and through the morning areas of fresh windslab were deposited in wind sheltered locations on mainly North to East aspects above 900 metres. These accumulations went through a period of instability early afternoon as the freezing level rose and the snowpack began to thaw. Some significant cornices remain and are prone to collapse in the mild conditions. Stability on other aspects tends to be better. The avalanche hazard is Considerable.

Summary: NC for 29.2. Windslab development N,NE and E aspects above 1000m. Cornices fragile in transient thaw. Avalanche Hazard Moderate.
SnowDistribution: Cloud base was at 1000 metres for most of the day, with blown snow reducing visibility at lower elevations. Winds approx 50-60 mph on north facing down slopes, progress was very difficult. Wind scoured and bare on aspects exposed to the wind, with heavy drifting on lee slopes.
Comment: A transient overnight thaw will improve stability slightly, before colder temperatures and windslab development continues through the day.
WeatherInfluences: Overnight rain at summit level is expected to gradually turn to sleet then snow above 600 metres during daylight hours. Winds will generally be gale force and from the South-West. The freezing level will be above the summits overnight, falling to around 700 metres by dawn.
SnowStability: Fresh accumulations of poorly bonded windslab will develop on North to East aspects above 1000 metres as the day progresses. Areas most affected will be steep wind sheltered locations, such as coire rims, gully tops and convexities where accumulations gain the greatest depth. Elsewhere, the moist snowpack will become firm with localised shallow accumulations of windblown snow at lower elevations. Cornices will be prone to collapse as temperatures fluctuate. The avalanche hazard will be Moderate.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Some light snow showers were followed by a mainly dry day. Gale force winds were from the West overnight, before backing to become storm force Southerlies by dawn. The freezing level rose from 1000 metres at midday, to reside above the summits by the end of the period.
ObservedSnowStability: Poorly bonded windslab was deposited on North to East aspects above 1000 metres. Further localised deposits are present on North-West aspects due to cross loading. The greatest instability remains in accumulations which contain a low density layer above firm snow at depth. Areas exposed to the wind have been scoured, leaving bare ground and firm older snow patches. Below 1000 metres the snow is stable, firm and features a widespread crust. The avalanche hazard is Moderate.
